newsitem.title: USA: US shrs end up as techs dazzle, Germany cuts rates.
newsitem.headline: US shrs end up as techs dazzle, Germany cuts rates.

text.p: U.S. stocks were swept higher by a rally in technology issues and a surprising steep German rate cut, which bolstered European bourses and renewed bullish sentiment on Wall Street.

News that the Bundesbank lowered its repurchase rate by 30 basis points to a historic low of 3.00 percent "was definitely a plus in a modest summer rally here, one that should take us to new highs," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers Global Economic Advisors.
After falling 31 Wednesday, the Dow rose 42 to about 5732.
The gain left the blue-chip index ever closer to its previous record closing high of 5778.00, set May 22.
The tech-laden Nasdaq Composite surged 17 points, or 1.51 percent, to about 1144.

"I think the bear market (in technology) is over. It's in a gut-wrenching bottoming process. High techs should be bought by aggressive investors. ... Six to nine months down the road they should be happy campers," said Alfred Goldman, technical research director at A.G. Edwards.
Stronger tech issues included Intel, up 2-3/4 to 83 after a Smith Barney upgrade, and Microsoft, up 1-1/2 to 125.
IBM added 3/8 to 113, Cisco Systems was up 1-3/8 to 57-5/8 and Hewlett-Packard rose 1-1/8 to 43.

Gainers beat losers 7-4 on moderate NYSE volume of about 354 million shares. The long bond slipped 1/32 to yield 6.84 percent as the German rate cut provided only a fleeting early boost. France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Austria and Canada followed with their own easings.

Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First, said, "The strength in foreign stock markets is due to the German rate cut. There's the expectation a further German cut will take the heat off other central bankers including our own."

But Lehman's Sinai did not see the Federal Reserve delaying any possible year-end tightening because of the Bundesbank's move. The Fed's decision will be based on "the question if there are any price inflation pressures percolating up. For fixed-income markets, the next big question is the August employment report."

Tobacco stocks remained under pressure as Oklahoma became the 14th state to sue the industry, and investors nervously awaited the outcome of a key tobacco liability case in Indianapolis. The case went to the jury Thursday. Philip Morris was the most-active NYSE issue, falling 3/4 to 86-7/8.
RJR Nabisco, parent of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, slipped 1/8 to 25-1/4, smokeless tobacco maker UST Inc fell 1/8 to 30-3/4, and Loews lost 1-1/2 to 75-1/8.

Among other issues, Zenith Electronics climbed 5-1/2 to 16-7/8 after programming venture Americast signed a $1 billion contract with Zenith to buy at least three million digital set-top boxes for its home entertainment service. Americast is a consortium comprised of Ameritech, South Corp, GTE, SBC Communications and Disney.
Kellogg lost 2-1/4 to 72-3/4. Prudential downgraded the stock to hold from buy.
Hershey Foods fell 1-1/4 to 87-1/4. Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock on a price basis.

SDL Inc slumped nine to 19 after the company forecast that revenue in the third quarter would be "at best" unchanged from the second quarter's $21.6 million because of manufacturing difficulties. Cowen cut its earnings estimates.
Dura Pharmaceutricals climbed 5-3/4 to 32-1/2 after Eli Lilly agreed to give Dura exclusive U.S. marketing rights to Lilly's patented Ceclor CD and Keftab antibiotics. Lilly inched up 3/8 to 59-3/4.
Veritas Software climbed eight to 48-1/4.
Veritas said it formed a strategic alliance with Microsoft for the delivery of its volume manager disk and storage management software in Microsoft's fast-growing operating system.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 17.12 to 1143.96.
The S&P 500 index rose 5.61 to 670.68.
(Figures official as of 1645 EDT/2045 GMT)
-- Wall Street desk, 212 859 1721
